word.entryDescription: the direction towards which the sun sets in the evening
word.entryExample: It rains a lot in the west.

word.entryDescription: rainy, or covered in water
word.entryExample: Oh no, my clothes are all wet!

word.entryDescription: a very large sea mammal that looks like a fish and breathes through a hole on the top of its head
word.entryExample: The whale is the biggest animal in the world.

word.entryDescription: one of the round things under a vehicle that turn and make it move
word.entryExample: My bike needs new wheels.

word.entryDescription: to breathe noisily and with difficulty
word.entryExample: Then I began to wheeze like this.

word.entryDescription: used to link two related but different facts together
word.entryExample: I like nature holidays, whereas my friend likes visiting cities.
While I'm not really scared of spiders or snakes, I would not go camping in Australia.

word.entryDescription: to spin in circles very quickly
word.entryExample: Leaves whirled in the wind.

word.entryDescription: something that is white is the colour of snow
word.entryExample: My cat is black and white.

word.entryDescription: complete and enthusiastic
word.entryExample: They were given a wholehearted approval.

word.entryDescription: one of two sets of special sticks that are stuck in the ground in a game of cricket, which the bowler tries to hit with the ball; or the area of ground between the two wickets
word.entryExample: The bowler runs up and throws the hard ball at the wicket.

word.entryDescription: having a large distance from one side to the other
word.entryExample: The river is very wide.

word.entryDescription: a female partner in a marriage
word.entryExample: The king talked about his wife, the queen, during our visit.

word.entryDescription: natural; not changed or controlled by humans
word.entryExample: I haven't seen many wild animals yet.

word.entryDescription: a natural area which has hardly been changed by humans
word.entryExample: You must be very well prepared before venturing into the wilderness.

word.entryDescription: wild plants and animals
word.entryExample: It is home to many types of wildlife including elephants, bears and monkeys.

word.entryDescription: clever, often using tricks
word.entryExample: The crow is said to be wily.

word.entryDescription: to be the most successful in competition with others
word.entryExample: We need to win this match to be the champions.

word.entryDescription: air moving above the ground which you can feel
word.entryExample: There's a strong wind outside.

word.entryDescription: energy extracted from air flow using wind turbines or sails to produce mechanical or electrical power
word.entryExample: The importance of government support for the future of wind energy was stressed by the company.

word.entryDescription: a flat piece of glass in a wall that allows light into a room
word.entryExample: You can see the playground through the window.

word.entryDescription: having a lot of wind
word.entryExample: It's a bit windy for cycling.

word.entryDescription: one of the parts on a bird, insect, or bat that move up and down and allow it to fly
word.entryExample: My pet parrot's got very colourful wings.

word.entryDescription: a person that wins a game (e.g. in sports)
word.entryExample: The first child to get to the top of the stairs is the winner.

word.entryDescription: the season with the coldest weather and the shortest days
word.entryExample: It's not very cold here in winter and we don't get a lot of snow.

word.entryDescription: knowledge of what is proper or reasonable; good sense or judgment
word.entryExample: Sarah had the wisdom to stop before she said too much.

word.entryDescription: to take money out of a bank account
word.entryExample: I'd like to withdraw a hundred pounds, please.

word.entryDescription: somebody who sees and can describe something such as a crime, or somebody who appears in court to state something about a case
word.entryExample: Detectives often find a lot of evidence from talking to witnesses.

word.entryDescription: an adult female human being
word.entryExample: Our teacher is a woman called Mrs Brown.

word.entryDescription: to think about something with curiosity
word.entryExample: She wondered how long I had been learning English.

word.entryDescription: a small forest
word.entryExample: We walked into a wood and we found a cave there.

word.entryDescription: a hard material which comes from trees
word.entryExample: Lots of furniture is made of wood.

word.entryDescription: made of wood
word.entryExample: I want a wooden horse.

word.entryDescription: the trees and other plants in a large, densely wooded area
word.entryExample: Yesterday we walked in the woods.

word.entryDescription: the soft, thick hair that grows on the bodies of sheep and some other animals
word.entryExample: We've got sheep on our farm which give us a lot of soft, white wool.

word.entryDescription: made of wool (a fabric which comes from sheep)
word.entryExample: This woollen coat is very warm.

word.entryDescription: a single unit of language that has a meaning
word.entryExample: What's the word for "friend" in Spanish?

word.entryDescription: to do something as a job
word.entryExample: She works in a hospital.

word.entryDescription: to make your body strong and fit by exercising
word.entryExample: Maybe you’d like to join the gym and work out with me?

word.entryDescription: manage to understand something
word.entryExample: I can't work out how to use this sewing machine – can you help me?

word.entryDescription: to work hard, in a determined way, without stopping
word.entryExample: Our dedicated team at the High Rocks rare bird sanctuary work tirelessly to ensure that these bird populations are protected.

word.entryDescription: the Earth and all the people, places, and things on it
word.entryExample: Is the elephant the biggest animal in the world?

word.entryDescription: everywhere in the world
word.entryExample: The bicycle industry in India exports bicycles and bicycle parts worldwide.

word.entryDescription: unhappy because you keep thinking about something unpleasant
word.entryExample: Going to the dentist makes William feel worried.

word.entryDescription: more unpleasant than something else, the comparative of 'bad'
word.entryExample: I think wind is worse than rain.

word.entryDescription: most unpleasant of all other things, the superlative of 'bad'
word.entryExample: Sport is my worst subject.

word.entryDescription: having value
word.entryExample: Although learning another language isn't easy, it is well worth all the dedication.

word.entryDescription: useful or important and therefore worth spending effort, time, money, etc on
word.entryExample: She thinks working as a doctor would be very satisfying and worthwhile.

word.entryDescription: a type of injury where the skin is open, or from which blood flows
word.entryExample: The wound was so deep that I was afraid that I'd have to go to hospital.

word.entryDescription: injured by a weapon
word.entryExample: The wounded soldier asked me to send a letter to his family.
